name: Meprobamate (Miltown)
summary: A carbamate-derivative anxiolytic historically used for anxiety disorders, largely replaced by benzodiazepines due to dependence risks.
description: Meprobamate is a carbamate-derivative anxiolytic and sedative-hypnotic that was widely prescribed in the 1950s and 1960s for the treatment of anxiety and tension. It acts as a central nervous system depressant, likely through modulation of GABA_A receptor function, although its exact mechanism is not fully understood. Due to significant risks of dependence, overdose, and withdrawal, it has largely been replaced by benzodiazepines and is now rarely used in most countries.

sections.text: Believed to act as a positive allosteric modulator of the GABA_A receptor, enhancing inhibitory neurotransmission and producing sedative and anxiolytic effects.

sections.geriatric: Lower initial doses recommended; increased risk of sedation and falls
sections.hepatic_impairment: Use caution; no formal dosing guidelines
sections.renal_impairment: Use caution; may accumulate in severe impairment

sections.text: Onset within 1 hour; duration of action approximately 6–8 hours.

other: High potential for dependence and abuse
Abrupt discontinuation can cause severe withdrawal symptoms, including seizures
Additive CNS depression with alcohol, opioids, and other sedatives

items: Signs of misuse, abuse, or dependence

sections.pregnancy: Category D; avoid unless benefits outweigh risks
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; not recommended
sections.pediatrics: Not recommended due to safety concerns

sections.text: Gradually reduce dose over 1–2 weeks or longer to minimize withdrawal risk.

items: Was one of the first widely used prescription anxiolytics before the introduction of benzodiazepines
Now considered obsolete in most countries due to safety profile
Withdrawal can be life-threatening if stopped abruptly
